ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: My understanding of quantum mechanics was solidified, and I got to see how quantum mechanics is used in various types of chemistry through computational calculations.
I learned a lot of math and physical skills.
Applications of Quantum Mechanics and Computational Chemistry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is one of the best I've taken at Yale. The content is interesting and it's designed in such a way that it's smooth to get through the content in the span of a semester. That being said, a discussion section or some sort of recurring office hours would have been really nice.

Professor Hammes-Schiffer makes the content digestible, but less so than the first half of the course. While her lecture slides were helpful and outlined all the derivations, I think it would have been more helpful to have worked through those derivations on the chalkboard in class, rather than jus show them on the screen.

The weakness is the method of delivery of information: using slides. I believe you cannot learn any math-heavy course by passively looking at the final results of the derivations; you have to go through them simultaneously with the instructor, who derives things on a blackboard.
More time going over specific problems
could be harder as an intro grad course
Interesting material but can be difficult to follow at times. Due to the variety of techniques, many were only covered for 30 minutes, making it difficult to truly appreciate how they work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! This course should be required for anyone thinking about studying quantum chemistry.

Yes! Great follow-up to the first half of the course. It goes into a little more depth at the end of the semester on electron spin and the resulting theories than CHEM 333, so you're able to see very clearly how the concepts you learn in pchem II and quantum play out in other realms of chemistry.
No. If you want to learn a quantum mechanics, pick a textbook and study it on your own, you'll have better retention
